content.description: Climb the face between Black Track (crack on the left) and Big Foot (bolted line to the right), using the arete where necessary
content.protection: bolted anchor at the top shared with Black Track, Big Foot, and Camel Toe

climbs.name: Sole Slasher aka Bigfoot
climbs.fa: Mark Robinson, Eric Keto, Al Rubin 1989

content.description: This is the four bolt sport route that climbs the face to the right of Black Track and shares the same anchor. There is a squeeze job sport route between these two lines that has had the hangers removed. Bigfoot starts a little ways up the right leaning ramp from ground level at a foot-shaped hueco.
content.protection: Four bolts and a chain anchor

content.description: It's a good idea to have a long stick clip as the first bolt is about 20 feet off the deck.  Very thin, fingery climbing on high quality, black-varnished sandstone. You can set up a toprope by leading "Left Out", which is a gear route, and dropping your rope down "Outrageous Fortune" with directional draws.
content.location: The bolted route in between "Left Out" and "Black Track."

content.description:
This is the obvious crack to the left of Black Track. 

  The start is alittle tricky for gear.Over all a very good route, and quite pumpy!The route ends at 2 bolts and can be rapped with a 60M rope.

This is an enjoyable route for those looking for new terrain.  I thought it was fun, even though it gets no stars in the new guidebook. 

  Scramble up easy but loose rock to the base of a A-framed chimney/roof feature.  Plug in some hand sized gear and enjoy the wild moves out of the roof.  Black varnish climbing leads to a short runout before a bolt.  Continue up on somewhat loose rock to the anchors on the 5.8 route to the left or the anchors above Left Out.
content.protection: Single set of cams to #3 camalot w/ emphasis on small gear, 2 #2 camalots are helpful for the bomb bay chimney/roof.
content.location: This is the first route to the left of Left Out.

content.description: A straightforward warm-up for the more interesting and challenging Big Foot
content.protection: Three bolts to a two-bolt chain anchor.  A couple mediocre gear placements exist to protect stepping off the boulder onto the face.  Feels less run-out than it looks
content.location: Near the top/far right of the large slabby boulder in the corner between the Black Track crack and the tan-colored steep face of Buffalo Balls

content.description: Route could be down graded if crack on the left is used.

Black Track is the obvious right leaning crack that goes up the middle of Hidden Falls Wall. The climb is well protected but is a bit off-width in places and can be a little clumsy. Otherwise, the climb is an excellent workout on hand and fist crack. When done, rappel the route with one rope. A short second pitch with two bolts on the face (5.11c) has also been done.
content.protection: A few medium to large nuts plus a full rack of cams up to 4 inches

content.description: This route was put up without a permit by some visiting climbers. The hangers have been pulled from the bolts. You can protect it with stoppers hung from the bolts. A short traverse right from the anchor will get you to the anchors for "left out"
content.protection: No bolts and little pro to be had. Build a trad anchor. Have your second traverse right to anchor on "leftout"
content.location: In lost creek canyon on the south wall. It starts on the large block 10' east of "left out"

content.description:
Hidden Falls Wall is a pleasant place to escape the heat of the summer, being in the shade for most of the day. It might get a sliver of sun briefly around 1pm in the summer but otherwise it remains quite cool. With six single pitch routes topping out at 100 feet, in the range of 5.9 to 5.11c, and with trad, sport and mixed, face and crack, there is a little something for everyone. Some routes can be top roped by climbing other routes. Descend by rappelling from bolt anchors. 

  Also known as Bigfoot Wall.
